Message.Title: NVDA future
Message.Msg: NVDA should be marching towards 20, yet its stuck in pre-teens. This is largely due to shift in PC market. The good news is that Jen was not asleep at the wheel and anticipated this shift by investing heavily in Mobile. This was not done at AMD and hence AMD is history. The landscape in mobile space is clearing though - QCOM is the biggest competition for NVDA and to effectively compete with QCOM, NVDA needs to make its integrated LTE strategy work. Then it will be game on! - Samsung will keep flogging Exynos on their products - TXN is essentially exiting app processor segment - MRVL and MediaTek are going no where fast (other than TD China) - ST-Ericsson has some traction - INTC is looking pathetic with Atom NVDA has strong OEM partnership. Microsoft, Google, Motorola, HTC, Asus (also ZTE, Fujitsu etc). NVDA needs to get a true volume product to show serious revenue growth. I think HTC One X+ will do very well but its only available on limited carriers. I expect NVDA to be a solid #2 behind QCOM by end of 2013. However, there are many risks along the way and I expect Q1 2013 to be a disappointment. That may be the right time to load up. Until then, its best to keep NVDA on watch list.

Topic.Title: PE calculation based on GAAP EPS. Why?

Message.Msg: This isn't accurate. The Intel licensing revs are included in the GPU segment's numbers. This has nothing to do with whether the GAAP or Non-GAAP numbers are used for the PE shown in sites like Yahoo Finance. The revenue from INTC's payments are included in both GAAP and non-GAAP numbers. The reason for GAAP vs non-GAAP EPS being used for the PE calculation in Yahoo Finance all comes down to which numbers the analysts report to Cap IQ and Thomson Reuters (Yahoo's data source). If you listen to enough conference calls, you'll here some companies specifically asking analysts to make sure they report the non GAAP numbers. AKAM is one company in specific where I've heard them do that. It is frustrating since a lot of people seem to take the Yahoo Finance numbers at face value and think they're making apple-to-apple comparisons, when they're not. And again, it has nothing to do with the INTC payments being treated differently on a GAAP or non GAAP basis. If you look the companies statements about their Non-GAAP numbers, the difference between the two is almost entirely around stock-based compensation.

Message.Title: Reuters Exclusive : AMD hires bank to explore options - sources
Message.Msg: Exclusive: AMD hires bank to explore options - sources By Nadia Damouni and Noel Randewich NEW YORK/SAN FRANCISCO | Tue Nov 13, 2012 6:23pm EST In excerpts. NEW YORK/SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Advanced Micro Devices has hired JPMorgan Chase & Co to explore options, which could include a sale, as the chipmaker struggles to find a role in an industry increasingly focused on mobile and away from traditional PCs, according to three sources familiar with the situation. One of Silicon Valley's oldest chipmakers, AMD is laying off engineers and some analysts are concerned it may not find new markets for its chips in time to reverse a declining cash reserve. AMD's shares have fallen more than 60 percent this year, giving it a market value of about $1.4 billion. It also has long-term debt and capital lease obligations of about $2 billion. Some investors believe part or all of AMD could be bought by a technology company that might want to emulate Apple Inc's tight control of software and components, a strategy credited in part for the success of the iPad and iPhone. Another source mentioned AMD's game console chip business and growing focus on embedded chips as the company's silver linings. Microsoft Corp, Google Inc, Samsung Electronics, Intel Corp and even Facebook Inc have been suggested by Wall Street analysts as potential suitors that could benefit from some of AMD's chip business, including its graphics division, PC processors and server chips. Goldman Sachs analyst James Covello estimated in a recent note to clients the chances of AMD's PC processor business being sold are between 15 percent and 30 percent." Be sure to read and re-read the whole Exclusive story from Reuters, boys. Google this : Exclusive: AMD hires bank to explore options - sources | Reuters Potential suitors, boys.
